awards.title: Awards
awards.award: Department of English Medal of Excellence

publications.title: Publications
publications.publication: Jenstad, Janelle, and Joseph Takeda (50%). "Making the RA Matter: Pedagogy, Interface, and Practices." Making Things and Drawing Boundaries: Experiments in the Digital Humanities. Ed. Jentery Sayers. Minnesota: University of Minnesota Press. Peer reviewed. Forthcoming. Expected publication: 2017.
Takeda, Joseph. "The MoEML Finding Aid to the Bills of Mortality." The Map of Early Modern London. Ed. Janelle Jenstad. University of Victoria. Forthcoming.

Project documentation and numerous encyclopedia articles on London places authored, co-authored, and edited for The Map of Early Modern London, including: "Barbican," and "Wood Street." For a full list of my contributions to MoEML, see http://mapoflondon.uvic.ca/TAKE1.htm.

conferences.title: Conference Presentations
conferences.conference: Holmes, Martin, and Joseph Takeda (50%). "Beyond Validation: using programmed diagnostics to learn about, monitor, and successfully complete your DH project." Digital Humanities 2017 conference. McGill University. August 11, 2017. PDF.
Jenstad, Janelle, Tye Landels-Gruenewald, and Joseph Takeda (33%). "Mapping the STC with MoEML and DEEP." Digital Humanities 2017 conference.. McGill University. August 09, 2017. PDF.
Takeda, Joseph. "The Fragility of Reconciliation: Reading The Book of Jessica. CSPT Graduate conference. University of Victoria. May 05, 2017.
Takeda, Joseph. "Viewing Jewish and Trans Identity: History, Genetics, and Jill Solowayâ€™s Transparent." Qualicum History conference. Parksville, British Columbia. January 28, 2017.

Jenstad, Janelle, Tye Landels-Gruenewald, and Joseph Takeda (33%). "How To Do Things with 6000 Toponyms." How To Do Things with Millions Of Words conference. University of British Columbia. November 03, 2016.

job.class: ENGL110: Indigenous and Multicultural Literature in Canada

job.desc: Using four digital humanities projects as case studies, the Endings partnership project attempts to develop workflows and best practices for finishing and archiving digital projects. At Endings, I developed tools and workflows for producing archivable, static projects from long-running projects.

title.ref: The Map of Early Modern London

job.desc: My work at the The Map of Early Modern London involved working in a variety of programming language and dialects (mostly XML based) to maintain the TEI-XML run website.

job.workplace: Scene Performance Journal, The Internet Shakespeare Editions
job.desc: Reporting to the Coordinating Editor, I liased with contributors, copy-edited reviews of performances of Shakespeare, and worked with XWiki and B2Evo blogging platforms.

At the ISE, I worked added to and correct the ISE's performance database, developed and maintained metadata (both a specialized vocabular and Dublin Core), and assisted with proofing for editions of Hamlet, Twelfth Night, and King Lear.

workplace.title: The Map of Dostoevsky's St. Petersburg
